Subject: Re: [neat] Bloat defeated!  (Maybe...)

At 17:34 25/02/2006, you wrote:
>Ian Badcoe wrote:
>
> >       I'll try to remember to leave it going while I'm at work tomorrow
> >and see how it does with another 3 or 4 million cycles.
> >
> >
>How did it go? Is it still running?
>
>Colin.

Well I had to kill it after a while because I discovered a bug in my 
experimental speciation code.

But the population sizes did remain in a very reasonable range for as 
long as I left it.

So I'm doing another run now, I started it yesterday morning and its 
nearly up to 4,000,000 cycles...

I've made a "SLEAT" folder in the files section and put a couple of 
graphs of it in there.  They may need a little explaining.  I'm using 
a prototype advanced speciation technique (oh, and I also use my 
EC-like "variance" parameter on all weights and FIDs, I don't know 
whether it helps but it certainly doesn't seem to hinder anything...).

So the speciation works that I run the main species (fitness in red) 
until it stalls for 100,000 cycles (the side population appears as 
zeros on the graphs during this phase).  Then I take one individual, 
mutate it to pieces and use it to see the side population.  I then 
run the side population until it stalls (the main population appears 
frozen at its last value during this phase).  I then merge the two 
populations (by one of several experimental techniques) overwrite the 
main population with the result, scrap the side-population and return 
to the initial phase (exolving main).

So far it has reached about 91.7%, which is very good for two days 
processing (compared to my previous speeds).

What I am thinking is, I will push this one for a little more to see 
if it can get much better, when I do think it's stalled, I will pull 
out the fittest individual and use it as a start-point for 
investigating further "stall busting" approaches.

Getting back to bloat, I think I have demonstrated an important point 
here, in that my previous "keep everything" breeding (e.g. the 
"standard" approach) was clearly never at equilibrium, and if you had 
seen these graphs for that (which you never could because it is so 
slow that we would all die of old-age waiting for them) the size 
curve would look pretty much exponential...

As you see, this new approach is much better behaved, and wobbles up 
and down in what looks to me far more like a random walk than a 
headlong charge towards infinity...

I am also inclined to say that the system as I have it has a net 
drive towards smaller individuals (look at the line of the purple and 
blue curves from 2.5 MCycles upwards) and that the individuals (i) 
grow in size when it is discovering additions that make then fitter, 
but, (ii) then slowly squeezes their existing fitness into a smaller 
genomes when they are not finding any obvious additions.

There's a solid mathematical reason why the net drive is downwards, 
which I am aching to explain to you all.  Does anybody want to know?

         Ian


In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
